channel.title: 60-Second Science
channel.description: Leading science journalists provide a daily minute commentary on some of the most interesting developments in the world of science. For a full-length, weekly podcast you can subscribe to Science Talk: The Podcast of Scientific American. To view all of our archived podcasts please go to www.scientificamerican.com/podcast
channel.copyright: 2012 Scientific American, a division of Nature America, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
channel.itunes:subtitle: A daily quick take on science.
channel.itunes:summary: Leading science journalists provide a daily minute commentary on some of the most interesting developments in the world of science. For a full-length, weekly podcast you can subscribe to Science Talk: The Podcast of Scientific American. To view all of our archived podcasts please go to www.scientificamerican.com/podcast
channel.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Mosquitoes Navigate Rain by Not Caring
item.description: Mosquitoes are so light that speeding raindrops simply brush them aside without imparting much force. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Mosquitoes Navigate Rain by Not Caring
item.itunes:summary: Mosquitoes are so light that speeding raindrops simply brush them aside without imparting much force. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Transit of Venus Draws Near
item.description: The 2012 transit of Venus can provide information of use to astronomers trying to understand the exoplanets around distant stars. John Matson reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Transit of Venus Draws Near
item.itunes:summary: The 2012 transit of Venus can provide information of use to astronomers trying to understand the exoplanets around distant stars. John Matson reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Test Cancer Drugs against Its Spread
item.description: A cancer expert argues that our current system for testing drugs fails to fully examine those that might stop metastasis. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Test Cancer Drugs against Its Spread
item.itunes:summary: A cancer expert argues that our current system for testing drugs fails to fully examine those that might stop metastasis. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Horse Hearers Know Who's Talking
item.description: When horses heard a familiar person's voice from a loudspeaker they preferentially looked at that person versus a stranger. Amy Kraft reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Horse Hearers Know Who's Talking
item.itunes:summary: When horses heard a familiar person's voice from a loudspeaker they preferentially looked at that person versus a stranger. Amy Kraft reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Streetlights Draw Insects at Ground Level
item.description: More insects, including many carnivores and scavengers, hang out under streetlights than between them, even during the day. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Streetlights Draw Insects at Ground Level
item.itunes:summary: More insects, including many carnivores and scavengers, hang out under streetlights than between them, even during the day. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Does Bad Dog Mean Bad Owner?
item.description: People expressing a preference for aggressive dog breeds scored higher for conscientiousness on a personality test than did those who liked gentler dogs. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Does Bad Dog Mean Bad Owner?
item.itunes:summary: People expressing a preference for aggressive dog breeds scored higher for conscientiousness on a personality test than did those who liked gentler dogs. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Cuttlefish Use Ancient Ink Formula
item.description: The melanin in modern-day cuttlefish ink is nearly chemically identical to the pigment found in ancient cephalopods' fossilized ink sacs. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Cuttlefish Use Ancient Ink Formula
item.itunes:summary: The melanin in modern-day cuttlefish ink is nearly chemically identical to the pigment found in ancient cephalopods' fossilized ink sacs. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Eating Fat Makes Mouse Brain Want More
item.description: Mice fed a high-fat diet make new cells in the hypothalamus, which may increase the desire to eat more. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Eating Fat Makes Mouse Brain Want More
item.itunes:summary: Mice fed a high-fat diet make new cells in the hypothalamus, which may increase the desire to eat more. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Babies' Attention Choices Fall within Goldilocks Zone
item.description: Babies quickly lost interest in a video when the material they were confronted with was either boringly simple or stultifyingly complex. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Babies' Attention Choices Fall within Goldilocks Zone
item.itunes:summary: Babies quickly lost interest in a video when the material they were confronted with was either boringly simple or stultifyingly complex. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: High-Ranking Baboons Heal Faster
item.description: The higher their social status, the less likely male baboons are to fall ill and the faster they recover from both illness and injury. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: High-Ranking Baboons Heal Faster
item.itunes:summary: The higher their social status, the less likely male baboons are to fall ill and the faster they recover from both illness and injury. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Management Steered Women Brokers into Pay Gap
item.description: A study of stockbroker data from the mid-'90s shows that management can affect women's pay even when that pay is based solely on commission. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Management Steered Women Brokers into Pay Gap
item.itunes:summary: A study of stockbroker data from the mid-'90s shows that management can affect women's pay even when that pay is based solely on commission. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Flavors Fluctuate with Temperature
item.description: Chilling or heating bitter, sour, sweet and astringent solutions changed their flavor intensity in different ways. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Flavors Fluctuate with Temperature
item.itunes:summary: Chilling or heating bitter, sour, sweet and astringent solutions changed their flavor intensity in different ways. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Mice Meal Times Influence Weight Gain
item.description: Mice that ate a high-fat diet within an eight-hour period daily gained less weight than mice that ate the same amount of food over the entire day. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Mice Meal Times Influence Weight Gain
item.itunes:summary: Mice that ate a high-fat diet within an eight-hour period daily gained less weight than mice that ate the same amount of food over the entire day. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Pesky Primate Plans Projectile Pitches
item.description: Santino the chimp collects and conceals rocks to throw at spectators at his zoo in Sweden. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Pesky Primate Plans Projectile Pitches
item.itunes:summary: Santino the chimp collects and conceals rocks to throw at spectators at his zoo in Sweden. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Whales Adjust Their Hearing Sensitivity
item.description: When warned of a loud noise, a false killer whale reduced its hearing sensitivity in anticipation of the sound. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Whales Adjust Their Hearing Sensitivity
item.itunes:summary: When warned of a loud noise, a false killer whale reduced its hearing sensitivity in anticipation of the sound. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Hot Jupiters Smarten Search for Other Earths
item.description: One way to limit the search for Earth-like exoplanets is to figure out where they cannot exist and eliminate those systems. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Hot Jupiters Smarten Search for Other Earths
item.itunes:summary: One way to limit the search for Earth-like exoplanets is to figure out where they cannot exist and eliminate those systems. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Nut-Cracking Chimps Demonstrate Cultural Differences
item.description: A chimpanzee's tool choice for cracking nuts depends on its community. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Nut-Cracking Chimps Demonstrate Cultural Differences
item.itunes:summary: A chimpanzee's tool choice for cracking nuts depends on its community. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Sharing Opinions Feels at Least as Good as Earning Money
item.description: Divulging personal details activated the reward center of subjects' brains, a feeling for which they were willing to sacrifice money. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Sharing Opinions Feels at Least as Good as Earning Money
item.itunes:summary: Divulging personal details activated the reward center of subjects' brains, a feeling for which they were willing to sacrifice money. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Creepy People Leave You Cold
item.description: A socially awkward or inappropriate person can make others feel physically colder. Amy Kraft reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Creepy People Leave You Cold
item.itunes:summary: A socially awkward or inappropriate person can make others feel physically colder. Amy Kraft reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Pork Order May Peak Odor
item.description: A proposed European ban on pig castration could make pork smell bad to people with the right genes. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Pork Order May Peak Odor
item.itunes:summary: A proposed European ban on pig castration could make pork smell bad to people with the right genes. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Genes Link Touch and Hearing
item.description: Tests with twins show that touch sensitivity is connected closely with hearing ability. Rose Eveleth reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Genes Link Touch and Hearing
item.itunes:summary: Tests with twins show that touch sensitivity is connected closely with hearing ability. Rose Eveleth reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Garlic Compound Fights Food-Borne Bacteria
item.description: Diallyl sulfide, a compound found in garlic, was much more effective than two standard antibiotics at wiping out bacteria responsible for digestive system infections. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Garlic Compound Fights Food-Borne Bacteria
item.itunes:summary: Diallyl sulfide, a compound found in garlic, was much more effective than two standard antibiotics at wiping out bacteria responsible for digestive system infections. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Obese People May Fail to Buckle Up
item.description: People of normal weight are 67 percent more likely to buckle their car seat belts than are obese people. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Obese People May Fail to Buckle Up
item.itunes:summary: People of normal weight are 67 percent more likely to buckle their car seat belts than are obese people. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Your Dog Wants Your Food
item.description: Dogs recognize and respond to human social signals to conclude that your food is more desirable than theirs. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Your Dog Wants Your Food
item.itunes:summary: Dogs recognize and respond to human social signals to conclude that your food is more desirable than theirs. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: "Pay What You Want" May Deter Consumers
item.description: Pay-what-you-want pricing may inadvertently give consumers the untenable choice to either pay more or feel cheap, driving them away from making a purchase at all. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: "Pay What You Want" May Deter Consumers
item.itunes:summary: Pay-what-you-want pricing may inadvertently give consumers the untenable choice to either pay more or feel cheap, driving them away from making a purchase at all. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Leeches Spill Guts about Elusive Mammals
item.description: Leeches can provide DNA evidence of the presence of rare mammals up to four months after having fed on one. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Leeches Spill Guts about Elusive Mammals
item.itunes:summary: Leeches can provide DNA evidence of the presence of rare mammals up to four months after having fed on one. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Brain Seeks the Voice among Many Speakers
item.description: Our brains focus on one speaker in a cacophony of voices based not only on the audio input we receive, but also on our listening goals. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Brain Seeks the Voice among Many Speakers
item.itunes:summary: Our brains focus on one speaker in a cacophony of voices based not only on the audio input we receive, but also on our listening goals. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:keywords: Cocktail party problem, multi-talker speech recognition
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Why Paper Yellows as It Ages
item.description: As paper ages, oxidation changes molecules in cellulose so that they absorb some wavelengths of light and make the paper look yellow. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Why Paper Yellows as It Ages
item.itunes:summary: As paper ages, oxidation changes molecules in cellulose so that they absorb some wavelengths of light and make the paper look yellow. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Ice Is Nice for Insect Bites
item.description: To relieve the annoying itch of insect bites, your best bet may be the simple application of ice to numb the bitten area and reduce inflammation. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Ice Is Nice for Insect Bites
item.itunes:summary: To relieve the annoying itch of insect bites, your best bet may be the simple application of ice to numb the bitten area and reduce inflammation. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Today Is Unlucky for People Who Have Bad Luck Today
item.description: A study of traffic accidents on Friday the 13th found that there are some. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Today Is Unlucky for People Who Have Bad Luck Today
item.itunes:summary: A study of traffic accidents on Friday the 13th found that there are some. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Anxiety Boosts Threat Odor Perception
item.description: Anxious men are especially good at detecting low concentrations of disagreeable scents, perhaps an evolutionary legacy of predator perception. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Anxiety Boosts Threat Odor Perception
item.itunes:summary: Anxious men are especially good at detecting low concentrations of disagreeable scents, perhaps an evolutionary legacy of predator perception. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Warmer Temps May Bollux Botanicals
item.description: Although higher temperatures can initially spur plant growth, the boost looks short-lived. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Warmer Temps May Bollux Botanicals
item.itunes:summary: Although higher temperatures can initially spur plant growth, the boost looks short-lived. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Free Apps Drain Battery
item.description: Some free apps use the majority of the energy they pull on tasks other than the app itself--such as uploading user info and downloading ads. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Free Apps Drain Battery
item.itunes:summary: Some free apps use the majority of the energy they pull on tasks other than the app itself--such as uploading user info and downloading ads. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Sparrows Sing Higher to Pierce Urban Din
item.description: White-crowned sparrows in San Francisco are singing in a higher pitch than they did in 1969 to be heard over louder traffic. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Sparrows Sing Higher to Pierce Urban Din
item.itunes:summary: White-crowned sparrows in San Francisco are singing in a higher pitch than they did in 1969 to be heard over louder traffic. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Lent End Means Hyena Free Lunch
item.description: In northern Ethiopia, hyenas must hunt more during Lent, when local Christians give up meat and provide fewer scraps to the scavengers. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Lent End Means Hyena Free Lunch
item.itunes:summary: In northern Ethiopia, hyenas must hunt more during Lent, when local Christians give up meat and provide fewer scraps to the scavengers. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Focused Students Put Down Their Smart Phones
item.description: More effective learners send and receive text messages less frequently during class. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Focused Students Put Down Their Smart Phones
item.itunes:summary: More effective learners send and receive text messages less frequently during class. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Programs Aim to Turn Science Undergrads into K-12 Teachers
item.description: At a higher education and science policy roundtable in New York City, University of Colorado at Boulder chancellor Philip DiStefano talked about his institution's efforts to attract science majors to teaching K-12. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Programs Aim to Turn Science Undergrads into K-12 Teachers
item.itunes:summary: At a higher education and science policy roundtable in New York City, University of Colorado at Boulder chancellor Philip DiStefano talked about his institution's efforts to attract science majors to teaching K-12. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: YouTube Winner Sends Spiders to Space
item.description: Amr Mohamed's winning entry in the YouTube Space Lab contest will have jumping spiders hunt in zero-gravity on the International Space Station. Mariette DiChristina reports
item.itunes:subtitle: YouTube Winner Sends Spiders to Space
item.itunes:summary: Amr Mohamed's winning entry in the YouTube Space Lab contest will have jumping spiders hunt in zero-gravity on the International Space Station. Mariette DiChristina reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Dengue Virus Makes Mosquitoes Better Spreaders
item.description: The dengue virus makes its mosquito hosts more bloodthirsty and quicker to find a blood meal, thus spreading the virus faster. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Dengue Virus Makes Mosquitoes Better Spreaders
item.itunes:summary: The dengue virus makes its mosquito hosts more bloodthirsty and quicker to find a blood meal, thus spreading the virus faster. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Struggling Young Readers Like Kindles
item.description: Middle school students in a reading improvement class liked using e-readers for a variety or reasons, and felt their reading improved as a result. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Struggling Young Readers Like Kindles
item.itunes:summary: Middle school students in a reading improvement class liked using e-readers for a variety or reasons, and felt their reading improved as a result. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Thyme Kills Acne Bacteria
item.description: Natural compounds in the herb thyme were more effective against acne-causing bacteria in cultures than were conventional treatments. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Thyme Kills Acne Bacteria
item.itunes:summary: Natural compounds in the herb thyme were more effective against acne-causing bacteria in cultures than were conventional treatments. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Rhythm and Music Help Math Students
item.description: Kids who learned fractions through a music-based curriculum outperformed peers in traditional math classes. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Rhythm and Music Help Math Students
item.itunes:summary: Kids who learned fractions through a music-based curriculum outperformed peers in traditional math classes. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Researchers Ferret Out Reasons for Runner's High
item.description: Dogs and humans release natural painkillers after running, but ordinarily sedentary ferrets that run do not. The chemical compounds may be an adaptation to reward the necessary behavior in running species. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Researchers Ferret Out Reasons for Runner's High
item.itunes:summary: Dogs and humans release natural painkillers after running, but ordinarily sedentary ferrets that run do not. The chemical compounds may be an adaptation to reward the necessary behavior in running species. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Classical Music Slows Mice Transplant Rejection
item.description: Mice with mismatched heart transplants that were exposed to classical music had much slower rejection rates than did mice exposed to other music and sounds. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Classical Music Slows Mice Transplant Rejection
item.itunes:summary: Mice with mismatched heart transplants that were exposed to classical music had much slower rejection rates than did mice exposed to other music and sounds. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Gun-Toting Increases Bias to See Guns Toted
item.description: A person holding a gun may be more likely to think they see a weapon being carried by another. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Gun-Toting Increases Bias to See Guns Toted
item.itunes:summary: A person holding a gun may be more likely to think they see a weapon being carried by another. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Emotion in Music Mirrors Speech
item.description: Tonal relationships that express emotions in classical South Indian music are similar to ones used in Western music, and both mimic vocalizations. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Emotion in Music Mirrors Speech
item.itunes:summary: Tonal relationships that express emotions in classical South Indian music are similar to ones used in Western music, and both mimic vocalizations. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Recycled Toilets Make Path Green
item.description: The Meador Kansas Ellis Trail became the first certified sustainable road under the Greenroads rating system, in part because it contains recycled commodes. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Recycled Toilets Make Path Green
item.itunes:summary: The Meador Kansas Ellis Trail became the first certified sustainable road under the Greenroads rating system, in part because it contains recycled commodes. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Frog Species Found in Big Apple
item.description: A previously unknown species of leopard frog has been found in an urban range centered on Yankee Stadium in New York City. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Frog Species Found in Big Apple
item.itunes:summary: A previously unknown species of leopard frog has been found in an urban range centered on Yankee Stadium in New York City. Christopher Intagliata reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Sex-Deprived Flies Seek Swig Solace
item.description: Sexually frustrated fruit flies preferred alcohol-laced food more than their satisfied compatriots did. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Sex-Deprived Flies Seek Swig Solace
item.itunes:summary: Sexually frustrated fruit flies preferred alcohol-laced food more than their satisfied compatriots did. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Green Laser Erases Print
item.description: Quick bursts of green laser light can erase print, without damaging or discoloring the paper. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Green Laser Erases Print
item.itunes:summary: Quick bursts of green laser light can erase print, without damaging or discoloring the paper. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Deeper Voice Gives Electoral Advantage
item.description: Study subjects tended to pick the deeper-voiced candidate when they heard anonymous voices purported to be running for office. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Deeper Voice Gives Electoral Advantage
item.itunes:summary: Study subjects tended to pick the deeper-voiced candidate when they heard anonymous voices purported to be running for office. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Your Mileage Price May Vary
item.description: Adjusted for inflation and for the better mileage you probably now get, the cost to go a mile may be cheaper than it was three decades ago. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Your Mileage Price May Vary
item.itunes:summary: Adjusted for inflation and for the better mileage you probably now get, the cost to go a mile may be cheaper than it was three decades ago. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Produce Consumption Ups Eater's Looks
item.description: Consuming more produce increases red and yellow colors in the skin of Caucasians, whom observers then rate as more attractive. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Produce Consumption Ups Eater's Looks
item.itunes:summary: Consuming more produce increases red and yellow colors in the skin of Caucasians, whom observers then rate as more attractive. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: QWERTY Keyboard Leads to Feelings about Words
item.description: Words with more letters on the right side of a QWERTY keyboard are thought of more positively than are words primarily typed on the left side. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: QWERTY Keyboard Leads to Feelings about Words
item.itunes:summary: Words with more letters on the right side of a QWERTY keyboard are thought of more positively than are words primarily typed on the left side. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Chimp Cops Arbitrate Disputes
item.description: High-ranking chimps in a group break up scuffles and keep the peace. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Chimp Cops Arbitrate Disputes
item.itunes:summary: High-ranking chimps in a group break up scuffles and keep the peace. Karen Hopkin reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: New Gels Heal Themselves--and Maybe You
item.description: Self-healing hydrogels may find uses in industry, including better plastics, as well as in medicine, such as the treatment of stomach perforations and ulcers. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:subtitle: New Gels Heal Themselves--and Maybe You
item.itunes:summary: Self-healing hydrogels may find uses in industry, including better plastics, as well as in medicine, such as the treatment of stomach perforations and ulcers. Sophie Bushwick reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Earthshine Sets Example for Life-Light Search
item.description: Researchers looking for life on exoplanets tried a proof-of-concept experiment by examining the light bouncing off Earth, via the moon. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Earthshine Sets Example for Life-Light Search
item.itunes:summary: Researchers looking for life on exoplanets tried a proof-of-concept experiment by examining the light bouncing off Earth, via the moon. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Psoriasis Linked to Protection from HIV-1
item.description: Many psoriasis patients have the same gene variants as people who are not significantly affected by an HIV-1 infection. Charles Q. Choi reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Psoriasis Linked to Protection from HIV-1
item.itunes:summary: Many psoriasis patients have the same gene variants as people who are not significantly affected by an HIV-1 infection. Charles Q. Choi reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Mars Swings into Opposition March 3
item.description: Every two years and two months Earth and Mars line up with the sun, giving us a relatively close view of the Red Planet. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Mars Swings into Opposition March 3
item.itunes:summary: Every two years and two months Earth and Mars line up with the sun, giving us a relatively close view of the Red Planet. Cynthia Graber reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American

item.title: Fish Finning Fails Financially
item.description: An economic analysis of the value of sharks for ecotourism alone finds that each individual is worth far more alive than dead for its fins. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:subtitle: Fish Finning Fails Financially
item.itunes:summary: An economic analysis of the value of sharks for ecotourism alone finds that each individual is worth far more alive than dead for its fins. Steve Mirsky reports
item.itunes:author: Scientific American
